🚀 𝗝𝗮𝘃𝗮 𝗝𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘆 – 𝗗𝗮𝘆 𝟮𝟬: 𝗝𝗮𝘃𝗮 𝟭𝟵 (𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟮) – 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲! ⚙️🧪Java 19 packs powerful previews and incubators, focusing on performance, platform evolution, and developer productivity. Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. It's an exciting step toward a more modern and concurrent Java! 💪📍 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘂𝗽 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘁:Java 20 – Polishing previews and pushing boundaries further! 🌟🔖hashtag#Java hashtag#JavaJourney hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#JavaFeatures hashtag#OOP hashtag#Programming hashtag#Coding hashtag#JavaVersions hashtag#Java19 hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#StructuredConcurrency hashtag#RecordPatterns hashtag#PatternMatching hashtag#BackendDev hashtag#JVM hashtag#ModernJava hashtag#JavaUpgrade hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#OpenJDK

Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

🔹 𝐃𝐚𝐲 70/100 - : 𝐉𝐒𝐏 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐄𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 – 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐬, 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬, 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬In JSP, Scripting Elements allow you to embed Java code directly into HTML. While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. 𝐔𝐬𝐞 𝐉𝐒𝐓𝐋 𝐨𝐫 𝐄𝐋 (𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐋𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐮𝐚𝐠𝐞) 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐜𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐧𝐞𝐫 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞.🔖 hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#AdvancedJava hashtag#JSP hashtag#JSPElements hashtag#Scriptlet hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#Day70

🚀 𝗝𝗮𝘃𝗮 𝗝𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘆 – 𝗗𝗮𝘆 𝟮𝟬: 𝗝𝗮𝘃𝗮 𝟭𝟵 (𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟮) – 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲! ⚙️🧪Java 19 packs powerful previews and incubators, focusing on performance, platform evolution, and developer productivity. Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. It's an exciting step toward a more modern and concurrent Java! 💪📍 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘂𝗽 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘁:Java 20 – Polishing previews and pushing boundaries further! 🌟🔖hashtag#Java hashtag#JavaJourney hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#JavaFeatures hashtag#OOP hashtag#Programming hashtag#Coding hashtag#JavaVersions hashtag#Java19 hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#StructuredConcurrency hashtag#RecordPatterns hashtag#PatternMatching hashtag#BackendDev hashtag#JVM hashtag#ModernJava hashtag#JavaUpgrade hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#OpenJDK

Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? I'm excited to share my latest IoT project that combines hardware, sensor data acquisition, and web technologies into a compact and intelligent water quality monitoring system—built using an ESP32 microcontroller.🔧💧 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 | 𝗘𝗦𝗣𝟯𝟮 + 𝗧𝗗𝗦 + 𝗗𝗦𝟭𝟴𝗕𝟮𝟬 + 𝗢𝗟𝗘𝗗 + 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿 🌐.🧠 Project Overview:This system is designed to measure Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Electrical Conductivity (EC), and water temperature using the DS18B20 temperature sensor and a TDS analog sensor. The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. ⚙️ Key Features & Functionalities:✅ Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation ✅ TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback ✅ OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (°C), and device IP address ✅ Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing ✅ Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network ✅ Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser ✅ Temperature in both °C and °F, auto-calculated 🖥️Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. ESP32 Dev Board (WiFi + Bluetooth)2. DS18B20 Digital Temperature Sensor (OneWire Protocol)3. Analog TDS Sensor (for ppm and EC readings)4. 0.96" I2C OLED Display (SSD1306)5. Arduino IDE for development6. C++/Embedded C for programming logic7. WiFi & HTTP Server Libraries for web hosting8. IEC 104 vs IEC 61850 — And Why a Unified Gateway MattersIn today’s energy systems, substation and SCADA protocols are evolving — and so must integration.Here’s how two key protocols differ:IEC 104✔️ SCADA-level protocol over TCP/IP✔️ Lightweight, reliable for RTU and remote data✔️ Ideal for control centers and grid monitoringIEC 61850✔️ Model-based substation protocol✔️ Supports GOOSE & MMS messaging✔️ Enables high-speed automation and IED interoperabilityBut modern systems don’t stop at substations.Our BOLA Gateway doesn’t just bridge IEC 104 and IEC 61850 —It also speaks MQTT, enabling seamless cloud integration for advanced analytics, dashboards, and alerting.So whether it’s control room, substation yard, or cloud platform —One gateway. Full visibility. Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? Share below! 👇hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#DailyJavaTrick hashtag#20DaysOfCode

I'm excited to share my latest IoT project that combines hardware, sensor data acquisition, and web technologies into a compact and intelligent water quality monitoring system—built using an ESP32 microcontroller.🔧💧 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 | 𝗘𝗦𝗣𝟯𝟮 + 𝗧𝗗𝗦 + 𝗗𝗦𝟭𝟴𝗕𝟮𝟬 + 𝗢𝗟𝗘𝗗 + 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿 🌐.🧠 Project Overview:This system is designed to measure Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Electrical Conductivity (EC), and water temperature using the DS18B20 temperature sensor and a TDS analog sensor. The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. ⚙️ Key Features & Functionalities:✅ Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation ✅ TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback ✅ OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (°C), and device IP address ✅ Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing ✅ Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network ✅ Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser ✅ Temperature in both °C and °F, auto-calculated 🖥️Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. ESP32 Dev Board (WiFi + Bluetooth)2. DS18B20 Digital Temperature Sensor (OneWire Protocol)3. Analog TDS Sensor (for ppm and EC readings)4. 0.96" I2C OLED Display (SSD1306)5. Arduino IDE for development6. C++/Embedded C for programming logic7. WiFi & HTTP Server Libraries for web hosting8. Adafruit GFX & SSD1306 Libraries for OLED UI🌱 Applications & Future Scope: 💧 Smart Agriculture – monitor irrigation water quality. 🐠 Aquaponics & Hydroponics systems. 🏠 Home water purification analysis. 📦 Future Upgrades: Blynk/ThingSpeak integration, cloud logging, push notifications, and solar-powered deployment.🎨𝘿𝙚𝙨𝙞𝙜𝙣𝙚𝙙, 𝙙𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙡𝙤𝙥𝙚𝙙, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙙𝙚𝙗𝙪𝙜𝙜𝙚𝙙 𝙗𝙮:Md Mizanur Rahman This project reflects my passion for IoT, embedded systems, and practical applications of sensor data to create sustainable and intelligent solutions.hashtag#IoT hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WaterQuality hashtag#TDS hashtag#Arduino hashtag#SmartFarming hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#WebDashboard hashtag#Electronics hashtag#MakersGonnaMake #IoTProjects#electrosurgeon#diyproject #linkedin#diy

IEC 104 vs IEC 61850 — And Why a Unified Gateway MattersIn today’s energy systems, substation and SCADA protocols are evolving — and so must integration.Here’s how two key protocols differ:IEC 104✔️ SCADA-level protocol over TCP/IP✔️ Lightweight, reliable for RTU and remote data✔️ Ideal for control centers and grid monitoringIEC 61850✔️ Model-based substation protocol✔️ Supports GOOSE & MMS messaging✔️ Enables high-speed automation and IED interoperabilityBut modern systems don’t stop at substations.Our BOLA Gateway doesn’t just bridge IEC 104 and IEC 61850 —It also speaks MQTT, enabling seamless cloud integration for advanced analytics, dashboards, and alerting.So whether it’s control room, substation yard, or cloud platform —One gateway. Full visibility. Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

🔹 𝐃𝐚𝐲 70/100 - : 𝐉𝐒𝐏 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐄𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 – 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐬, 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬, 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬In JSP, Scripting Elements allow you to embed Java code directly into HTML. While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. 𝐔𝐬𝐞 𝐉𝐒𝐓𝐋 𝐨𝐫 𝐄𝐋 (𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐋𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐮𝐚𝐠𝐞) 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐜𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐧𝐞𝐫 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞.🔖 hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#AdvancedJava hashtag#JSP hashtag#JSPElements hashtag#Scriptlet hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#Day70

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? Share below! 👇hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#DailyJavaTrick hashtag#20DaysOfCode

I'm excited to share my latest IoT project that combines hardware, sensor data acquisition, and web technologies into a compact and intelligent water quality monitoring system—built using an ESP32 microcontroller.🔧💧 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 | 𝗘𝗦𝗣𝟯𝟮 + 𝗧𝗗𝗦 + 𝗗𝗦𝟭𝟴𝗕𝟮𝟬 + 𝗢𝗟𝗘𝗗 + 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿 🌐.🧠 Project Overview:This system is designed to measure Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Electrical Conductivity (EC), and water temperature using the DS18B20 temperature sensor and a TDS analog sensor. The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. ⚙️ Key Features & Functionalities:✅ Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation ✅ TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback ✅ OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (°C), and device IP address ✅ Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing ✅ Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network ✅ Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser ✅ Temperature in both °C and °F, auto-calculated 🖥️Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. ESP32 Dev Board (WiFi + Bluetooth)2. DS18B20 Digital Temperature Sensor (OneWire Protocol)3. Analog TDS Sensor (for ppm and EC readings)4. 0.96" I2C OLED Display (SSD1306)5. Arduino IDE for development6. C++/Embedded C for programming logic7. WiFi & HTTP Server Libraries for web hosting8. Adafruit GFX & SSD1306 Libraries for OLED UI🌱 Applications & Future Scope: 💧 Smart Agriculture – monitor irrigation water quality. 🐠 Aquaponics & Hydroponics systems. 🏠 Home water purification analysis. 📦 Future Upgrades: Blynk/ThingSpeak integration, cloud logging, push notifications, and solar-powered deployment.🎨𝘿𝙚𝙨𝙞𝙜𝙣𝙚𝙙, 𝙙𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙡𝙤𝙥𝙚𝙙, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙙𝙚𝙗𝙪𝙜𝙜𝙚𝙙 𝙗𝙮:Md Mizanur Rahman This project reflects my passion for IoT, embedded systems, and practical applications of sensor data to create sustainable and intelligent solutions.hashtag#IoT hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WaterQuality hashtag#TDS hashtag#Arduino hashtag#SmartFarming hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#WebDashboard hashtag#Electronics hashtag#MakersGonnaMake #IoTProjects#electrosurgeon#diyproject #linkedin#diy

IEC 104 vs IEC 61850 — And Why a Unified Gateway MattersIn today’s energy systems, substation and SCADA protocols are evolving — and so must integration.Here’s how two key protocols differ:IEC 104✔️ SCADA-level protocol over TCP/IP✔️ Lightweight, reliable for RTU and remote data✔️ Ideal for control centers and grid monitoringIEC 61850✔️ Model-based substation protocol✔️ Supports GOOSE & MMS messaging✔️ Enables high-speed automation and IED interoperabilityBut modern systems don’t stop at substations.Our BOLA Gateway doesn’t just bridge IEC 104 and IEC 61850 —It also speaks MQTT, enabling seamless cloud integration for advanced analytics, dashboards, and alerting.So whether it’s control room, substation yard, or cloud platform —One gateway. Full visibility. hashtag#على_رف_الكتب رحلتي مع كتاب نظم المعلومات – كيف يدير العالم الرقمي الأعمال؟عن الكتابInformation Systems Today: Managing in the Digital World هو كتاب أكاديمي معتمد في العديد من الجامعات حول العالم، يُدرّس في مقررات نظم المعلومات الإدارية (MIS).يتكوّن من 10 فصول، تغطي موضوعات مثل: التحول الرقمي، الميزة التنافسية، التجارة الإلكترونية، ذكاء الأعمال، أنظمة ERP/CRM/SCM، وأمن المعلوماتيستعرض الكتاب كيف أصبحت نظم المعلومات عنصرًا حاسمًا في نجاح الأعمال، من خلال: •	إدارة سلسلة التوريد (SCM) •	إدارة علاقات العملاء (CRM) •	التحليلات الذكية وذكاء الأعمال (BI) •	الحوسبة السحابية وإنترنت الأشياء (IoT) •	أمن المعلومات والخصوصيةالكتاب غني بالأمثلة الواقعية ودراسات الحالة التي تربط المفاهيم النظرية بالتطبيقات العملية في بيئة الأعمال الرقمية.⸻👨‍🏫 عن المؤلفين •	Joseph S. Valacich: أستاذ بارز في نظم المعلومات، يُعتبر من أكثر الباحثين إنتاجًا في مجال نظم المعلومات الإدارية، وله إسهامات بحثية عديدة في هذا المجال. •	Christoph Schneider: أكاديمي متخصص في نظم المعلومات، يركز في أبحاثه على التفاعل بين الإنسان والحاسوب وتأثيرات التكنولوجيا على سلوك المستخدمين.في زمن تتسارع فيه التقنية وتتغير فيه طرق الإدارة، جاء كتاب Information Systems Today – ليقدّم رؤية شاملة وعملية عن دور نظم المعلومات في دعم المنظمات واتخاذ القرارات وتحقيق الميزة التنافسية.الكتاب يشرح كيف أصبحت نظم المعلومات هي القلب النابض للمنظمات الحديثة، من خلال محاور متعددة تشمل: •	الاتصال والتعاون داخل فرق العمل، سواء كانت تقليدية أو افتراضية. •	ذكاء الأعمال (BI) والتحليلات المتقدمة لاتخاذ قرارات مبنية على البيانات. •	الأنظمة المؤسسية (ERP و CRM و SCM) التي تُوحّد العمليات عبر الأقسام. •	التكامل بين المنظمات والعملاء والموردين من خلال تقنيات الحوسبة السحابية، والبوابات الرقمية، وأنظمة التفاعل اللحظي. •	وأخيرًا، يناقش الجانب الإنساني والتقني في إدارة البيانات والخصوصية والتحول الرقمي.ما يميز هذا الكتاب أنه لا يقتصر على النظريات، بل يربطها بأمثلة عالمية وتطبيقات عملية تعكس واقع بيئة الأعمال.لكل طالب إدارة، تقنية، أو حتى مبتكر رقمي، أنصح بقراءته لفهم البنية الرقمية التي تقوم عليها أي منظمة ناجحة اليوملماذا أنصح به؟إذا كنت طالبًا في مجال نظم المعلومات، أو محترفًا يسعى لفهم كيفية توظيف التكنولوجيا في تحسين أداء الأعمال، فإن هذا الكتاب يُعد مرجعًا أساسيًا يجمع بين النظرية والتطبيق، ويُقدم رؤية شاملة عن تحديات وفرص العالم الرقمي

Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But let’s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8–5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didn’t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us what’s possible. 2025 is showing us who’s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

🔴 تعالي نشرح أهمية تفعيل ال GET/PUT communication في Siemens في قصة قصيرة.📌 سنعتبر الآتي :القلعة المحصنة هي ال PLC 🏰 ملك القلعة هو انت المبرمج 👷 باب القلعة السحري هو ال PUT/GET ⛩️ التاجر هو ال OPC Client 👨‍💼 📍 في يوم من الأيام، جاء تاجر ذكي اسمه OPC، وقال لحراس القلعة:"يا جماعة! أريد أن أدخل وأرى الوصفات داخل القلعة أريد أن أقرأ وأكتب معلومات!"لكن الحراس ردوا عليه بصرامة:"آسف يا OPC، القلعة مغلقة… لا أحد يدخل أو يخرج إلا بأمر الملك!"ولكن في هذه القلعة، يوجد باب سحري اسمه GET/PUT Access. هذا الباب لا يُفتح إلا إذا قرر الملك (المبرمج) أن يسمح بذلك.لو لم تفتح هذا الباب ⬅️ OPC سيبقى بالخارج، يصرخ، يحاول، لكن الحراس سيرفضون طلبه!لو فتحت الباب ⬅️ الحراس سيقولون: أهلاً وسهلاً يا OPC، تفضل، يمكنك أن تأخذ أو تضع المعلومات التي تريدها!لكن… فتح هذا الباب له مخاطره:"يا ملكنا، لو فتحت هذا الباب، ربما يأتي ناس غرباء أو أعداء يحاولون الدخول وسرقة المعلومات!"📌 الشرح العلمي:وحدات S7-1200 وS7-1500 تمنع الوصول المباشر إلى الذاكرة (DBs) في ال PLC من جهاز خارجي ( مثل ال SCADA او HMI او PLC اخر ) حفاظًا على الأمان.✅ لذلك، إذا أردت أن يستطيع OPC Client قراءة أو كتابة البيانات مباشرة من/إلى الـ PLC ⬅️ يجب أن تفعل خيار PUT/GET Access داخل إعدادات الـ PLC.❌ بدون هذا التفعيل الـ PLC سيقوم برفض أي اتصال خارجي يحاول قراءة البيانات باستخدام S7 Protocol من جهاز خارجي (مثل OPC Client).ضروري تفعيله لو تريد تشغيل SCADA أو HMI خارجي (غير Siemens) يقرأ مباشرة من الـ PLC.🚩 ملاحظة مهمة:تفعيل GET/PUT يقلل مستوى الأمان (لأنه يسمح لأي جهاز يملك IP ومعرفة العنوان بالوصول). لذلك:لو الشبكة مفتوحة أو معرضة ⬅️ يفضل حماية الوصول بكلمة مرور أو VLAN.أو ⬅️  استخدام وسائل اتصال أخرى أكثر أمانًا مثل OPC UA مع تشفير وشهادات.✅ أين يتم التفعيل؟في TIA Portal:اختر PLC في Project Tree.ادخل على Properties.اذهب إلى Protection & Security.فعّل الخيار:Allow GET/PUT communication from remote partner (PLC, HMI, OPC, etc.)🟢 بمجرد التفعيل، الـ OPC Client يستطيع الوصول للبيانات المخزنة في Data Blocks القابلة للقراءة/الكتابة.hashtag#OPC hashtag#Clien hashtag#OP_UA hashtag#Communication hashtag#PLC hashtag#SCADA hashtag#HMI hashtag#Automation hashtag#Siemens hashtag#GET hashtag#PUT hashtag#Security hashtag#Tia_Portal hashtag#Tia hashtag#S7 hashtag#Industrial

🚀 𝗝𝗮𝘃𝗮 𝗝𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘆 – 𝗗𝗮𝘆 𝟮𝟬: 𝗝𝗮𝘃𝗮 𝟭𝟵 (𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟮) – 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲! ⚙️🧪Java 19 packs powerful previews and incubators, focusing on performance, platform evolution, and developer productivity. Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? I'm excited to share my latest IoT project that combines hardware, sensor data acquisition, and web technologies into a compact and intelligent water quality monitoring system—built using an ESP32 microcontroller.🔧💧 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 | 𝗘𝗦𝗣𝟯𝟮 + 𝗧𝗗𝗦 + 𝗗𝗦𝟭𝟴𝗕𝟮𝟬 + 𝗢𝗟𝗘𝗗 + 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿 🌐.🧠 Project Overview:This system is designed to measure Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Electrical Conductivity (EC), and water temperature using the DS18B20 temperature sensor and a TDS analog sensor. The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. ⚙️ Key Features & Functionalities:✅ Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation ✅ TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback ✅ OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (°C), and device IP address ✅ Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing ✅ Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network ✅ Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser ✅ Temperature in both °C and °F, auto-calculated 🖥️Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. ESP32 Dev Board (WiFi + Bluetooth)2. DS18B20 Digital Temperature Sensor (OneWire Protocol)3. Analog TDS Sensor (for ppm and EC readings)4. 0.96" I2C OLED Display (SSD1306)5. Arduino IDE for development6. C++/Embedded C for programming logic7. WiFi & HTTP Server Libraries for web hosting8. IEC 104 vs IEC 61850 — And Why a Unified Gateway MattersIn today’s energy systems, substation and SCADA protocols are evolving — and so must integration.Here’s how two key protocols differ:IEC 104✔️ SCADA-level protocol over TCP/IP✔️ Lightweight, reliable for RTU and remote data✔️ Ideal for control centers and grid monitoringIEC 61850✔️ Model-based substation protocol✔️ Supports GOOSE & MMS messaging✔️ Enables high-speed automation and IED interoperabilityBut modern systems don’t stop at substations.Our BOLA Gateway doesn’t just bridge IEC 104 and IEC 61850 —It also speaks MQTT, enabling seamless cloud integration for advanced analytics, dashboards, and alerting.So whether it’s control room, substation yard, or cloud platform —One gateway. Full visibility. hashtag#على_رف_الكتب رحلتي مع كتاب نظم المعلومات – كيف يدير العالم الرقمي الأعمال؟عن الكتابInformation Systems Today: Managing in the Digital World هو كتاب أكاديمي معتمد في العديد من الجامعات حول العالم، يُدرّس في مقررات نظم المعلومات الإدارية (MIS).يتكوّن من 10 فصول، تغطي موضوعات مثل: التحول الرقمي، الميزة التنافسية، التجارة الإلكترونية، ذكاء الأعمال، أنظمة ERP/CRM/SCM، وأمن المعلوماتيستعرض الكتاب كيف أصبحت نظم المعلومات عنصرًا حاسمًا في نجاح الأعمال، من خلال: •	إدارة سلسلة التوريد (SCM) •	إدارة علاقات العملاء (CRM) •	التحليلات الذكية وذكاء الأعمال (BI) •	الحوسبة السحابية وإنترنت الأشياء (IoT) •	أمن المعلومات والخصوصيةالكتاب غني بالأمثلة الواقعية ودراسات الحالة التي تربط المفاهيم النظرية بالتطبيقات العملية في بيئة الأعمال الرقمية.⸻👨‍🏫 عن المؤلفين •	Joseph S. Valacich: أستاذ بارز في نظم المعلومات، يُعتبر من أكثر الباحثين إنتاجًا في مجال نظم المعلومات الإدارية، وله إسهامات بحثية عديدة في هذا المجال. •	Christoph Schneider: أكاديمي متخصص في نظم المعلومات، يركز في أبحاثه على التفاعل بين الإنسان والحاسوب وتأثيرات التكنولوجيا على سلوك المستخدمين.في زمن تتسارع فيه التقنية وتتغير فيه طرق الإدارة، جاء كتاب Information Systems Today – ليقدّم رؤية شاملة وعملية عن دور نظم المعلومات في دعم المنظمات واتخاذ القرارات وتحقيق الميزة التنافسية.الكتاب يشرح كيف أصبحت نظم المعلومات هي القلب النابض للمنظمات الحديثة، من خلال محاور متعددة تشمل: •	الاتصال والتعاون داخل فرق العمل، سواء كانت تقليدية أو افتراضية. •	ذكاء الأعمال (BI) والتحليلات المتقدمة لاتخاذ قرارات مبنية على البيانات. •	الأنظمة المؤسسية (ERP و CRM و SCM) التي تُوحّد العمليات عبر الأقسام. •	التكامل بين المنظمات والعملاء والموردين من خلال تقنيات الحوسبة السحابية، والبوابات الرقمية، وأنظمة التفاعل اللحظي. •	وأخيرًا، يناقش الجانب الإنساني والتقني في إدارة البيانات والخصوصية والتحول الرقمي.ما يميز هذا الكتاب أنه لا يقتصر على النظريات، بل يربطها بأمثلة عالمية وتطبيقات عملية تعكس واقع بيئة الأعمال.لكل طالب إدارة، تقنية، أو حتى مبتكر رقمي، أنصح بقراءته لفهم البنية الرقمية التي تقوم عليها أي منظمة ناجحة اليوملماذا أنصح به؟إذا كنت طالبًا في مجال نظم المعلومات، أو محترفًا يسعى لفهم كيفية توظيف التكنولوجيا في تحسين أداء الأعمال، فإن هذا الكتاب يُعد مرجعًا أساسيًا يجمع بين النظرية والتطبيق، ويُقدم رؤية شاملة عن تحديات وفرص العالم الرقمي

Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But let’s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8–5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didn’t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us what’s possible. 2025 is showing us who’s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

🔴 تعالي نشرح أهمية تفعيل ال GET/PUT communication في Siemens في قصة قصيرة.📌 سنعتبر الآتي :القلعة المحصنة هي ال PLC 🏰 ملك القلعة هو انت المبرمج 👷 باب القلعة السحري هو ال PUT/GET ⛩️ التاجر هو ال OPC Client 👨‍💼 📍 في يوم من الأيام، جاء تاجر ذكي اسمه OPC، وقال لحراس القلعة:"يا جماعة! أريد أن أدخل وأرى الوصفات داخل القلعة أريد أن أقرأ وأكتب معلومات!"لكن الحراس ردوا عليه بصرامة:"آسف يا OPC، القلعة مغلقة… لا أحد يدخل أو يخرج إلا بأمر الملك!"ولكن في هذه القلعة، يوجد باب سحري اسمه GET/PUT Access. هذا الباب لا يُفتح إلا إذا قرر الملك (المبرمج) أن يسمح بذلك.لو لم تفتح هذا الباب ⬅️ OPC سيبقى بالخارج، يصرخ، يحاول، لكن الحراس سيرفضون طلبه!لو فتحت الباب ⬅️ الحراس سيقولون: أهلاً وسهلاً يا OPC، تفضل، يمكنك أن تأخذ أو تضع المعلومات التي تريدها!لكن… فتح هذا الباب له مخاطره:"يا ملكنا، لو فتحت هذا الباب، ربما يأتي ناس غرباء أو أعداء يحاولون الدخول وسرقة المعلومات!"📌 الشرح العلمي:وحدات S7-1200 وS7-1500 تمنع الوصول المباشر إلى الذاكرة (DBs) في ال PLC من جهاز خارجي ( مثل ال SCADA او HMI او PLC اخر ) حفاظًا على الأمان.✅ لذلك، إذا أردت أن يستطيع OPC Client قراءة أو كتابة البيانات مباشرة من/إلى الـ PLC ⬅️ يجب أن تفعل خيار PUT/GET Access داخل إعدادات الـ PLC.❌ بدون هذا التفعيل الـ PLC سيقوم برفض أي اتصال خارجي يحاول قراءة البيانات باستخدام S7 Protocol من جهاز خارجي (مثل OPC Client).ضروري تفعيله لو تريد تشغيل SCADA أو HMI خارجي (غير Siemens) يقرأ مباشرة من الـ PLC.🚩 ملاحظة مهمة:تفعيل GET/PUT يقلل مستوى الأمان (لأنه يسمح لأي جهاز يملك IP ومعرفة العنوان بالوصول). لذلك:لو الشبكة مفتوحة أو معرضة ⬅️ يفضل حماية الوصول بكلمة مرور أو VLAN.أو ⬅️  استخدام وسائل اتصال أخرى أكثر أمانًا مثل OPC UA مع تشفير وشهادات.✅ أين يتم التفعيل؟في TIA Portal:اختر PLC في Project Tree.ادخل على Properties.اذهب إلى Protection & Security.فعّل الخيار:Allow GET/PUT communication from remote partner (PLC, HMI, OPC, etc.)🟢 بمجرد التفعيل، الـ OPC Client يستطيع الوصول للبيانات المخزنة في Data Blocks القابلة للقراءة/الكتابة.hashtag#OPC hashtag#Clien hashtag#OP_UA hashtag#Communication hashtag#PLC hashtag#SCADA hashtag#HMI hashtag#Automation hashtag#Siemens hashtag#GET hashtag#PUT hashtag#Security hashtag#Tia_Portal hashtag#Tia hashtag#S7 hashtag#Industrial

Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? I'm excited to share my latest IoT project that combines hardware, sensor data acquisition, and web technologies into a compact and intelligent water quality monitoring system—built using an ESP32 microcontroller.🔧💧 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 | 𝗘𝗦𝗣𝟯𝟮 + 𝗧𝗗𝗦 + 𝗗𝗦𝟭𝟴𝗕𝟮𝟬 + 𝗢𝗟𝗘𝗗 + 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿 🌐.🧠 Project Overview:This system is designed to measure Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Electrical Conductivity (EC), and water temperature using the DS18B20 temperature sensor and a TDS analog sensor. The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. ⚙️ Key Features & Functionalities:✅ Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation ✅ TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback ✅ OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (°C), and device IP address ✅ Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing ✅ Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network ✅ Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser ✅ Temperature in both °C and °F, auto-calculated 🖥️Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. ESP32 Dev Board (WiFi + Bluetooth)2. DS18B20 Digital Temperature Sensor (OneWire Protocol)3. Analog TDS Sensor (for ppm and EC readings)4. 0.96" I2C OLED Display (SSD1306)5. hashtag#على_رف_الكتب رحلتي مع كتاب نظم المعلومات – كيف يدير العالم الرقمي الأعمال؟عن الكتابInformation Systems Today: Managing in the Digital World هو كتاب أكاديمي معتمد في العديد من الجامعات حول العالم، يُدرّس في مقررات نظم المعلومات الإدارية (MIS).يتكوّن من 10 فصول، تغطي موضوعات مثل: التحول الرقمي، الميزة التنافسية، التجارة الإلكترونية، ذكاء الأعمال، أنظمة ERP/CRM/SCM، وأمن المعلوماتيستعرض الكتاب كيف أصبحت نظم المعلومات عنصرًا حاسمًا في نجاح الأعمال، من خلال: •	إدارة سلسلة التوريد (SCM) •	إدارة علاقات العملاء (CRM) •	التحليلات الذكية وذكاء الأعمال (BI) •	الحوسبة السحابية وإنترنت الأشياء (IoT) •	أمن المعلومات والخصوصيةالكتاب غني بالأمثلة الواقعية ودراسات الحالة التي تربط المفاهيم النظرية بالتطبيقات العملية في بيئة الأعمال الرقمية.⸻👨‍🏫 عن المؤلفين •	Joseph S. Valacich: أستاذ بارز في نظم المعلومات، يُعتبر من أكثر الباحثين إنتاجًا في مجال نظم المعلومات الإدارية، وله إسهامات بحثية عديدة في هذا المجال. •	Christoph Schneider: أكاديمي متخصص في نظم المعلومات، يركز في أبحاثه على التفاعل بين الإنسان والحاسوب وتأثيرات التكنولوجيا على سلوك المستخدمين.في زمن تتسارع فيه التقنية وتتغير فيه طرق الإدارة، جاء كتاب Information Systems Today – ليقدّم رؤية شاملة وعملية عن دور نظم المعلومات في دعم المنظمات واتخاذ القرارات وتحقيق الميزة التنافسية.الكتاب يشرح كيف أصبحت نظم المعلومات هي القلب النابض للمنظمات الحديثة، من خلال محاور متعددة تشمل: •	الاتصال والتعاون داخل فرق العمل، سواء كانت تقليدية أو افتراضية. •	ذكاء الأعمال (BI) والتحليلات المتقدمة لاتخاذ قرارات مبنية على البيانات. •	الأنظمة المؤسسية (ERP و CRM و SCM) التي تُوحّد العمليات عبر الأقسام. •	التكامل بين المنظمات والعملاء والموردين من خلال تقنيات الحوسبة السحابية، والبوابات الرقمية، وأنظمة التفاعل اللحظي. •	وأخيرًا، يناقش الجانب الإنساني والتقني في إدارة البيانات والخصوصية والتحول الرقمي.ما يميز هذا الكتاب أنه لا يقتصر على النظريات، بل يربطها بأمثلة عالمية وتطبيقات عملية تعكس واقع بيئة الأعمال.لكل طالب إدارة، تقنية، أو حتى مبتكر رقمي، أنصح بقراءته لفهم البنية الرقمية التي تقوم عليها أي منظمة ناجحة اليوملماذا أنصح به؟إذا كنت طالبًا في مجال نظم المعلومات، أو محترفًا يسعى لفهم كيفية توظيف التكنولوجيا في تحسين أداء الأعمال، فإن هذا الكتاب يُعد مرجعًا أساسيًا يجمع بين النظرية والتطبيق، ويُقدم رؤية شاملة عن تحديات وفرص العالم الرقمي

Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But let’s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8–5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didn’t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us what’s possible. 2025 is showing us who’s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

🔴 تعالي نشرح أهمية تفعيل ال GET/PUT communication في Siemens في قصة قصيرة.📌 سنعتبر الآتي :القلعة المحصنة هي ال PLC 🏰 ملك القلعة هو انت المبرمج 👷 باب القلعة السحري هو ال PUT/GET ⛩️ التاجر هو ال OPC Client 👨‍💼 📍 في يوم من الأيام، جاء تاجر ذكي اسمه OPC، وقال لحراس القلعة:"يا جماعة! أريد أن أدخل وأرى الوصفات داخل القلعة أريد أن أقرأ وأكتب معلومات!"لكن الحراس ردوا عليه بصرامة:"آسف يا OPC، القلعة مغلقة… لا أحد يدخل أو يخرج إلا بأمر الملك!"ولكن في هذه القلعة، يوجد باب سحري اسمه GET/PUT Access. هذا الباب لا يُفتح إلا إذا قرر الملك (المبرمج) أن يسمح بذلك.لو لم تفتح هذا الباب ⬅️ OPC سيبقى بالخارج، يصرخ، يحاول، لكن الحراس سيرفضون طلبه!لو فتحت الباب ⬅️ الحراس سيقولون: أهلاً وسهلاً يا OPC، تفضل، يمكنك أن تأخذ أو تضع المعلومات التي تريدها!لكن… فتح هذا الباب له مخاطره:"يا ملكنا، لو فتحت هذا الباب، ربما يأتي ناس غرباء أو أعداء يحاولون الدخول وسرقة المعلومات!"📌 الشرح العلمي:وحدات S7-1200 وS7-1500 تمنع الوصول المباشر إلى الذاكرة (DBs) في ال PLC من جهاز خارجي ( مثل ال SCADA او HMI او PLC اخر ) حفاظًا على الأمان.✅ لذلك، إذا أردت أن يستطيع OPC Client قراءة أو كتابة البيانات مباشرة من/إلى الـ PLC ⬅️ يجب أن تفعل خيار PUT/GET Access داخل إعدادات الـ PLC.❌ بدون هذا التفعيل الـ PLC سيقوم برفض أي اتصال خارجي يحاول قراءة البيانات باستخدام S7 Protocol من جهاز خارجي (مثل OPC Client).ضروري تفعيله لو تريد تشغيل SCADA أو HMI خارجي (غير Siemens) يقرأ مباشرة من الـ PLC.🚩 ملاحظة مهمة:تفعيل GET/PUT يقلل مستوى الأمان (لأنه يسمح لأي جهاز يملك IP ومعرفة العنوان بالوصول). لذلك:لو الشبكة مفتوحة أو معرضة ⬅️ يفضل حماية الوصول بكلمة مرور أو VLAN.أو ⬅️  استخدام وسائل اتصال أخرى أكثر أمانًا مثل OPC UA مع تشفير وشهادات.✅ أين يتم التفعيل؟في TIA Portal:اختر PLC في Project Tree.ادخل على Properties.اذهب إلى Protection & Security.فعّل الخيار:Allow GET/PUT communication from remote partner (PLC, HMI, OPC, etc.)🟢 بمجرد التفعيل، الـ OPC Client يستطيع الوصول للبيانات المخزنة في Data Blocks القابلة للقراءة/الكتابة.hashtag#OPC hashtag#Clien hashtag#OP_UA hashtag#Communication hashtag#PLC hashtag#SCADA hashtag#HMI hashtag#Automation hashtag#Siemens hashtag#GET hashtag#PUT hashtag#Security hashtag#Tia_Portal hashtag#Tia hashtag#S7 hashtag#Industrial

When NVS Fails on ESP32… LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weird—some configs didn’t load properly, and things just didn’t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldn’t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. 😬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! 🏋  Everything became stable and clean again.🔍 A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wall—hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

Let's dive in! 👇🧬 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 (Preview)✅ Lightweight threads to simplify high-throughput concurrency✅ Ideal for scalable server apps𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳 = 𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴.𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘝𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘌𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳()) { 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘰𝘳.𝘴𝘶𝘣𝘮𝘪𝘵(() -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘭𝘰 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘥"));}🏗️ 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 (Incubator)✅ Treat related tasks as a single unit✅ Makes multithreaded code easier to manage and cancel𝘵𝘳𝘺 (𝘷𝘢𝘳 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦 = 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘛𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘚𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘚𝘩𝘶𝘵𝘥𝘰𝘸𝘯𝘖𝘯𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘶𝘳𝘦()) { 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘜𝘴𝘦𝘳()); 𝘍𝘶𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦<𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨> 𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳 = 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘬(() -> 𝘧𝘦𝘵𝘤𝘩𝘖𝘳𝘥𝘦𝘳()); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘫𝘰𝘪𝘯(); 𝘴𝘤𝘰𝘱𝘦.𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘐𝘧𝘍𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘦𝘥();}🔣 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵 (Preview)✅ Cleaner, safer switch logic✅ Supports type patterns and guarded patterns𝘴𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘤𝘩 (𝘰𝘣𝘫) { 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘴.𝘵𝘰𝘓𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘊𝘢𝘴𝘦()); 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯(𝘪 * 2); 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘢𝘶𝘭𝘵 -> 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘜𝘯𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘯");}📦 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 (Preview)✅ Deconstruct records directly in pattern matching✅ Boosts readability and conciseness𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘳𝘥 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺) {}𝘪𝘧 (𝘰𝘣𝘫 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘰𝘧 𝘗𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘵(𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘹, 𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘺)) { 𝘚𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮.𝘰𝘶𝘵.𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘯("𝘟 = " + 𝘹 + ", 𝘠 = " + 𝘺);}📶 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗣𝗜 (Third Incubator)✅ Safer native interop (replacing JNI)✅ Access native memory and call C libraries directly🧪 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘅/𝗥𝗜𝗦𝗖-𝗩 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁✅ Adds official support for Linux on RISC-V architecture✅ Expands Java's reach to emerging hardware📌 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆:Java 19 delivers innovation through preview & incubator features like virtual threads, pattern matching for switch, and record patterns. Remote work is the dream we all signed up for. But like anything that sounds too good to be true, it does have a dark side.Here are five 5 uncomfortable realities about working from home:𝟭. "𝗢𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁, 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱."The saying still holds weight. When you're not physically present, you risk becoming invisible. Without face-to-face interactions, you may find promotions and projects slipping through your fingers.𝟮. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗿𝘆."Remote work is freedom—until it isn’t. The boundaries between work and personal time start to fade. Your workday stretches into your evening, and before you know it, you're answering emails before breakfast.𝟯. "𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲."You’ve got Slack, Zoom, and Teams, but something’s missing. The organic exchanges—the brainstorms that happen between meetings—are gone. The spontaneity that builds great ideas fades. Culture, too, is harder to nurture in a digital-first world.𝟰. "𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺."Remote work means working alone. Team lunches? Gone. Casual chats? Rare. Without intentional effort, loneliness creeps in. The social side of work can be easily overlooked when you’re on your own all day.𝟱. "𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲."No one’s watching you. No one’s asking if you’ve hit your goals. It’s all on you. Remote work demands high self-discipline. Without it, procrastination will become your full-time job.Remote work is not just about location—it’s about mindset. "Freedom" is only meaningful when you’ve built the habits to manage it.hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#DigitalWorkplace hashtag#HybridWork

While modern practices discourage heavy use of these, it's still important to understand them.✍️ 1. 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐭 (<% ... %>)-Used to write Java code blocks-Placed inside the _jspService() method<% 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐧𝐮𝐦 = 5; 𝐨𝐮𝐭.𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐧("𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬: " + 𝐧𝐮𝐦);%>🔢 2. 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%= ... %>)-Outputs the result of a Java expression-Automatically converted to out.print(...)<𝐩>𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐬: <%= 5 * 5 %></𝐩>)🧾 3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 (<%! ... %>)-Declares methods or variables at the class level-Not inside _jspService() — gets compiled outside<%! 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 = 0; %><%! 𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐝𝐝(𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐚, 𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐛) { 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐚 + 𝐛; } %>𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧 𝐉𝐒𝐏. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.🧠 Understanding == vs .equals() in Java🔍 The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2🧪 The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."🖼️ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.🎮 Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}📌 Follow along and challenge yourself daily!💡 I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. 🚀🔔 Follow me to get these updates!💬 Which Java trick interests you most? I'm excited to share my latest IoT project that combines hardware, sensor data acquisition, and web technologies into a compact and intelligent water quality monitoring system—built using an ESP32 microcontroller.🔧💧 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 | 𝗘𝗦𝗣𝟯𝟮 + 𝗧𝗗𝗦 + 𝗗𝗦𝟭𝟴𝗕𝟮𝟬 + 𝗢𝗟𝗘𝗗 + 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿 🌐.🧠 Project Overview:This system is designed to measure Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Electrical Conductivity (EC), and water temperature using the DS18B20 temperature sensor and a TDS analog sensor. The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. ⚙️ Key Features & Functionalities:✅ Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation ✅ TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback ✅ OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (°C), and device IP address ✅ Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing ✅ Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network ✅ Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser ✅ Temperature in both °C and °F, auto-calculated 🖥️Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. ESP32 Dev Board (WiFi + Bluetooth)2. DS18B20 Digital Temperature Sensor (OneWire Protocol)3. Analog TDS Sensor (for ppm and EC readings)4. 0.96" I2C OLED Display (SSD1306)5.
